Topic.Title: U.S. appeals court to Google: Your injunction in Germany is nonsense. Now go FRAND your patents.

"Now, did you Google, sign the United National agreement regarding FRAND licensing?" "Speak up now boys." "You're mumbling at your shoes again."

Topic.Title: Intel's Clover Trail power software still a no-show; tablet delays likely (news gaining momentum on the web)

Message.Msg: False. Microsoft has said that the Windows RT tablets (e.g. those powered by Tegra 3) will be available the day of the launch, but the Windows Pro tablets (powered by Intel/Clover Trail) would come months later. The new rumors seem to line up with that. If anything the delay of the Intel-based tabs will drive additional marginal sales for the Surface RT, Asus Vivo Tab RT, Lenovo Windows RT Tab, etc. since they will be the only ones on the market.

Message.Title: MS Kinect took 4 months to sell 10M units
Message.Msg: Totally different product, totally different product, and selling to base of enthusiastic Xbox360 users -- but still, as a data point in favor of MSFT's potential selling devices to consumers. They went from 0 to 10M sales in just over 4 months. If the Surface RT tablet even approached that, it'd make the Surface RT the most successful design win for NVDA Tegra to date (unless the Nexus 7 sales are actually much higher than analyst forecasts). disclosure: I'm long on NVDA

Topic.Title: Barrons: NIVIDIA, Intel can advance in "app chips", says Wells Fargo's David Wong

Message.Msg: I agree, and don't think NVDA's potential in the baseband market with Icera's soft modem is priced into the stock. That said, I think getting baseband integrated into the Tegra SoCs is absolutely critical for their viability competing against QCOM in the US and MediaTek in China -- and eventually Intel, assuming Infineon eventually allows Atom to become a connected SoC. The market seems to be pricing in very low odds of them succeeding, which for longs (like me) seems to present a lot of upside if they actually execute.

Message.Title: NVDA: Will It Make You A Millionaire?
Message.Msg: Who knows…I do know one thing for sure, big players like Google and Apple sure wont! Might be worth taking a chance one some of these smaller players…to make sure you have the right trend analysis and up to date info while doing your research on NVDA check this out. Copy & Paste this to your browser -- mcaf.ee/e5clr

Topic.Title: Barrons: NIVIDIA, Intel can advance in "app chips", says Wells Fargo's David Wong

Message.Msg: I think Jen-Hsun has also said (maybe on the Q1 conference call?) that the company perceives the larger near-term opportunity to be with Icera discrete/standalone baseband solutions as opposed to the integrated SoCs -- you one could imagine Samsung or Intel complementing the Exynos or Atom SoCs with Icera modems in designs, much as they currently do with qualcomm (and several other suppliers). The market has some big competitors, but back when Nvidia made the acquisition, Icera was said to be 1-2 years ahead of the competition in terms of performance and efficiency -- smaller and even less power-hungry than what's on the market today.

Topic.Title: Value stocks anyone? - Intel, Microsoft, Ciscos, HP

Message.Msg: SeekingAlpha: Cisco, Intel, Microsoft, Hewlett-Packard: Value Stocks, Seriously! "Cisco (CSCO), Intel (INTC), and Microsoft (MSFT) have all followed a similar path: founded in the '70s and '80s; expanding to unbelievable size and influence throughout the '90s; settling back somewhat as the technology-Internet bubble popped; and then finally recovering to become huge, mega-cap, and mega-profitable enterprises with stable, increasing dividends. While Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) -- founded in 1939, and a public company since 1957 -- comes from a different era, the spin-off in 1999 of its non-computer businesses to become Agilent Technologies." There is no mention of nvidia whatsoever. Not a peep. Maybe it's because nvidia has; -- Not expanded to unbelievable size. -- Not had any influence throughout the '90s. -- Not recovered after settling back somewhat. -- Not become a huge, mega-cap. -- Not become a mega-profitable enterprise. -- Certaintly nvidia does not have stable, increasing dividends. -- In fact, nvidia has paid zero dividends in it's entire 19 year history. Litle nvidia has done none of the things those other good technology companies have.

Topic.Title: this high PE is not justified

Message.Msg: --- Wayne w/ i410 LTE side by side: Q2/2013 --- Grey (Tegra 3 & i500 integrated LTE): Q4/2013 In other words, this is Dead Money for at least a year. Probably longer. Since nvidia has a tradition of Everything always being late. In the interim -- the southward slide in nvda continues. Such as today, for example.

Topic.Title: this high PE is not justified

Message.Msg: Even if "Wayne" doesn't ship until Q2/2013, it will likely still be on display and any design wins will be hyped up at CES in early January. There are potential nearer-term catalysts, though, like the launch of Windows RT in a few weeks. Of course pricing will be key -- but I expect it'll be a positive catalyst for Nvidia if it turns out that Microsoft has a penetration pricing strategy with the Surface RT. Then there's Q3 earnings in expected to be reported in the second week of November. We'll see if management was accurate with their raised forecasts for Q3 and whether they also guide up for Q4. I believe FY2013 (the current calendar year) is on pace to a record year for Nvidia in terms of revenue, which is a strong attestation to the argument that their business is decoupled from the trends in the broader PC market.

Topic.Title: this high PE is not justified

Message.Msg: "There's $5.29 in cash per share." It appears that the current CEO is too chicken to put that cash to work. Heck, after the last diasterous acquisition -- icera -- who can blame him for being gun shy, right? But always remember boys -- A buck is only worth a buck. Nothing more. And investors aren't paying 17.28 TIMES EARNINGS to watch dumb cash gather dust in some bank account. While the current CEO frets and dawdles about what to do with it. Nope. There is no multiple applied to dumb cash. None. Bottom Line: This place needs to generate some real GAAP Net Income -- and quick -- or that overly lofty P/E will be taken to the woodshed. By the Impatient Market. "Put it to work to generate earnings, or pay it out. Or find a new visionary CEO who will."

Message.Title: Qualcomm introduces three (3) more quad-core Snapdragon S4's with integrated radios.
Message.Msg: Qualcomm announces new quad-core Snapdragon S4 processors with reference design counterpart for smartphones Steve Shen, DIGITIMES [Monday 1 October 2012] "Qualcomm has announced the addition of two new Snapdragon S4 mobile processors: the MSM8225Q and MSM8625Q. Both are members of the Snapdragon S4 Play processor tier, optimized specifically for smartphone users. Snapdragon S4 Play processors will now offer OEMs both dual-core and quad-core CPUs and performance for entry-level smartphones, with the more advanced version featuring higher bus bandwidth, larger screen resolution support, HD video and enhanced user experiences, according to the vendor. Both processors will be ready for customer sampling by end of 2012 and are expected to be shipping in commercial devices in the first quarter of 2013. The MSM8225Q and MSM8625Q processors incorporate quad-core CPUs and are the upgraded software compatible variants of the Snapdragon S4 Play MSM8225 and MSM8625 processors, which both feature dual-core CPUs and dual SIM support. The quad-core variants will support LPDDR2 memory, increasing the bus bandwidth for improved features such as 720p display and 720p video encode and decode. Snapdragon S4 Play MSM8625Q features Qualcomm's integrated multimode UMTS/CDMA modem, and the MSM8225Q has an integrated UMTS modem. Both processors enable Wi-Fi, Bluetooth 4.0 and FM connectivity using the Qualcomm Atheros AR6005 and WCN2243 chips, the company said. In addition, Qualcomm also announced a single platform, the Snapdragon S4 Plus MSM8930, that supports all China operators with UMTS, CDMA and TD-SCDMA. Furthermore, this single platform will support LTE -TDD and TD-SCDMA, targeting mid-tier smartphones for use in China. Announced in February 2011, this processor features dual-core CPUs and as a single-chip solution with an integrated LTE modem, it is designed to take LTE to high-volume smartphones. Snapdragon S4 Plus MSM8930 with LTE-TDD and TD-SCDMA support will be ready for customer sampling by the end of 2012 and is expected to be shipping in commercial devices by the first quarter of 2013, Qualcomm said. Qualcomm will also be releasing Qualcomm Reference Design (QRD) versions of all three processors. The QRD program includes handset development platforms and an ecosystem program providing access to third-party providers of tested and verified hardware and software components so customers can deliver differentiated smartphones to consumers, the firm said. The Wi-Fi, Bluetooth and FM connectivity technologies have been pre-validated and tested with the QRD platform to provide reduced time-to-market. There have been more than 50 public QRD-based product launches to date in collaboration with more than 40 OEMs, and there are 100 designs in progress, including QRD-based smartphones enabled by these new Snapdragon S4 Play and Plus processors, which are also expected to be available by the first quarter of 2013, it said. The new Snapdragon S4 Play and Plus processors are designed specifically for High-Volume smartphones, and they provide device manufacturers the ability to migrate their existing Snapdragon S1-based designs to S4 dual- and quad-core CPU-based designs." In separate news, phones powered by the icera/nvidia LTE integrated Grey chip might not even be available until the End of 2013.

Topic.Title: Nexus 7 Sales Volume: Estimate Based on Supply Chain Data

Message.Msg: More sales of Tegra 3 CPUs does not translate to better margins. As a matter of fact, Tegra margins are below average. Most of NVDA's profit seems to come from Intel royalty payments which will go away after three years. NVDA has a good chance to buy out AMD for less than $2.5B, and should do so to get more competitive against Intel.
